snippet.textDisplay:
They labled the olfactory region of the brain as taste: major no no.
What I don't love about La Croix is that the "flavor" in dependent on olfactory perception. Without gustatory perception, the nose is left detecting chemicals and the gustatory perception is water or in the case of La Croix carbonated water. Air Up = placebo effect.
snippet.textOriginal:
They labled the olfactory region of the brain as taste: major no no. 
What I don't love about La Croix is that the "flavor" in dependent on olfactory perception. Without gustatory perception, the nose is left detecting chemicals and the gustatory perception is water or in the case of La Croix carbonated water. Air Up = placebo effect.

snippet.textDisplay:
Or, you could pour your left over coffee grounds onto your wheelbarrow herb garden. They're really high in nitrogen, so if you're growing something for it's leafy goodness, then you can get extra benefit from them that way. If you want to review a citrus squeezer, try the one from Joseph Joseph. I used to get pain in my joints, which made it hard to squeeze citrus by hand, and found it really helpful. I still use it, just because it's easy and convenient, and I don't get my hands sticky and covered in lime juice, when I'm squeezing it over madras curry. They also have a folding chopping board, which might be a nice one to review.

Hrrm... what if you put some of the gadgets you've reviewed on a table, and for the Ultimate Battle Curveball, they have to select one (or it's selected for them), which they MUST use (even if it would be quicker to complete a task by hand...)
snippet.textOriginal:
Or, you could pour your left over coffee grounds onto your wheelbarrow herb garden. They're really high in nitrogen, so if you're growing something for it's leafy goodness, then you can get extra benefit from them that way. If you want to review a citrus squeezer, try the one from Joseph Joseph. I used to get pain in my joints, which made it hard to squeeze citrus by hand, and found it really helpful. I still use it, just because it's easy and convenient, and I don't get my hands sticky and covered in lime juice, when I'm squeezing it over madras curry. They also have a folding chopping board, which might be a nice one to review.

Hrrm... what if you put some of the gadgets you've reviewed on a table, and for the Ultimate Battle Curveball, they have to select one (or it's selected for them), which they MUST use (even if it would be quicker to complete a task by hand...)

snippet.textDisplay:
What i think is even more valid about the "air up" bottle thing is that you get by without the acid.
All those flavoured waters, and even worse, the bottles where you can put fruit shavings in or what have you have a lot of 'hidden' accid that ruins your teeth, especially if you use them as a substitute for normal water and keep sipping over days on end. After two days of apple slices in water you literally change the accidity in your mouth enough to make the enamel on your teeth slowly melt away by errosion alone, and causes you to actually scrape a fair amount away each time you brush your teeth. And so few people talk about how much that f's you and your teeth up in the long run.
It's even worse than with soda, because instead of consuming a large amount in one sitting, most people spread their water intake over the day in small sips.
snippet.textOriginal:

All those flavoured waters, and even worse, the bottles where you can put fruit shavings in or what have you have a lot of 'hidden' accid that ruins your teeth, especially if you use them as a substitute for normal water and keep sipping over days on end. After two days of apple slices in water you literally change the accidity in your mouth enough to make the enamel on your teeth slowly melt away by errosion alone, and causes you to actually scrape a fair amount away each time you brush your teeth. And so few people talk about how much that f's you and your teeth up in the long run.
It's even worse than with soda, because instead of consuming a large amount in one sitting, most people spread their water intake over the day in small sips.

snippet.textDisplay: I HAVE to say something because I've owned one of the lemon pouring things for years and YOU DONT USE IT RIGHT. They work so well I'm so disappointed you used them wrong 😭😭😭😭

snippet.textDisplay: Okay...I'd get the candy box if it didn't look so childish. If it had a more contemporary style (made out of wood, stone or metal) and had a better style, I'd definitely get it for a fancy dinner party. I don't need the Rookie Stix because I know how to use chopsticks. I'd get the lemon juicer. Pretty cool and it saves a little time instead of rolling the lemon, cutting the lemon and then squeezing the juice out either by hand or a lemon squeezer. I would not get the scoof since  I don't drink coffee. And lastly, I would definitely, definitely, definitely get Air Up! That is so cool! And that company making those flavor rings to fit regular bottles of bottled water would be amazing!!!
snippet.textOriginal: Okay...I'd get the candy box if it didn't look so childish. If it had a more contemporary style (made out of wood, stone or metal) and had a better style, I'd definitely get it for a fancy dinner party. snippet.textDisplay: As a parent, I looked for those chopsticks forever (they're not a new product at all), and couldn't find any. They're great if you don't use chopsticks that often and have little kids. I was 6 before I could use chopsticks, my oldest was 6 before she could, I doubt my younger child will learn before he is 6. Unless you use chopsticks often enough for a small child to pick up the skill, those things are invaluable.

snippet.textDisplay: The first product is quite popular among south east asians. Its common practice during the lunar new year to go house visiting (wishing your friends and family well for the new year and all that jazz). A lot of the time, the traditional snacks, sweets and other small food items are placed in one of those. And since most people expect about 4-5 different families a day during the visiting period, you really want a container big enough to contain all those snacks but diverse enough so that you don't have to keep running back and forth to the kitchen to get people's preferred snack. So I have seen that all my life growing up and its a little astounding that they just wrote it off as useless.
snippet.textOriginal: The first product is quite popular among south east asians. Its common practice during the lunar new year to go house visiting (wishing your friends and family well for the new year and all that jazz). A lot of the time, the traditional snacks, sweets and other small food items are placed in one of those. And since most people expect about 4-5 different families a day during the visiting period, you really want a container big enough to contain all those snacks but diverse enough so that you don't have to keep running back and forth to the kitchen to get people's preferred snack. So I have seen that all my life growing up and its a little astounding that they just wrote it off as useless.

snippet.textDisplay: @ the air-up: just wanted to point out that, after doing a microbial growth on agar plates using my water bottle with a straw as the sample, I can safely say for myself that water bottles with straws and nozzles are absolutely disgusting. Please everyone remember to put your straws and nozzles/lids through the dishwasher on the warmest setting, or boil them in water for 15 minutes if they can handle that (which silicon usually can!), the more often the better. I do it at least once a week! Trust me, you don't want to use a water bottle nozzle/straw for more than a week or two without cleaning it properly. If you can't boil them and don't have a dishwasher, put them in vinegar or salt solutions, or freeze them!
snippet.textOriginal: @ the air-up: just wanted to point out that, after doing a microbial growth on agar plates using my water bottle with a straw as the sample, I can safely say for myself that water bottles with straws and nozzles are absolutely disgusting. Please everyone remember to put your straws and nozzles/lids through the dishwasher on the warmest setting, or boil them in water for 15 minutes if they can handle that (which silicon usually can!), the more often the better. I do it at least once a week! Trust me, you don't want to use a water bottle nozzle/straw for more than a week or two without cleaning it properly. If you can't boil them and don't have a dishwasher, put them in vinegar or salt solutions, or freeze them!

snippet.textDisplay: Hey guys, as always, love your videos! Anyways, just wanted to give you an idea of how we use the first gadget in Asia. It's actually a pretty common item to have here. When we celebrate Chinese New Year, which is the start of the lunar new year (its a whole thing, different calendar and stuff. Won't bore you with the details), we use similar candy boxes to put small portion of different snacks for our family members to enjoy when they meet up at our house for the family reunion. Most of the snacks came in big bottles and taking out a small portion to put in one place means less opening and closing of different bottles. Also, a lot of the snacks are liable to become 'soft' (google love letters food. Yes, it's a thing.) if they aren't sealed properly, which tends to happen if you have kids opening your stuff for snacks. Those boxes save space on the table too, since it won't be cluttered with various bottles. Well, that's all. Oh, congratulations on the wedding, Mike! :D
snippet.textOriginal: Hey guys, as always, love your videos! Anyways, just wanted to give you an idea of how we use the first gadget in Asia. It's actually a pretty common item to have here. When we celebrate Chinese New Year, which is the start of the lunar new year (its a whole thing, different calendar and stuff. Won't bore you with the details), we use similar candy boxes to put small portion of different snacks for our family members to enjoy when they meet up at our house for the family reunion. Most of the snacks came in big bottles and taking out a small portion to put in one place means less opening and closing of different bottles. Also, a lot of the snacks are liable to become 'soft' (google love letters food. Yes, it's a thing.) if they aren't sealed properly, which tends to happen if you have kids opening your stuff for snacks. Those boxes save space on the table too, since it won't be cluttered with various bottles. Well, that's all. Oh, congratulations on the wedding, Mike! :D

snippet.textDisplay:
The first one isn't useless. It's not utilitarian; it's presentational. Presentation is a use. You could serve the same things you'd put in it in tupperware, instead, but that would be bad presentation, and that gadget serves a purpose.

The water bottle, however, is proprietary, and the circles are made to only fit the plastic bottle that they make. And if the product doesn't sell well, it will have been another source of even more plastic waste. Also, there's a really unfortunate misconception about soda causing obesity, and the statistical correlation between the two being conflated. Soda itself is actually fine. It's sugar water, and sugar is, contrary to the current dietary fad of misinformation, not unhealthy, and is actually difficult to biologically have too much of. Weight gain itself is a multifactor thing, and it involves genetics and lifestyle (such as exercise). In fact, diet is one of the least contributing factors, and genetics is extremely more significant. Sugar itself is actually the chemical that human biology evolved to use as the necessary chemical for basic function and energy transfer. Protein and vitamins are what your body is built out of; not what makes it go. The ATP cycle uses sugar, specifically. Without it, you'd go into ketosis, which can be lethal. Soda is factually, biologically, fine. It's not "causing" obesity. It is nowhere close to that simple. And dietary health is based mostly on what your body is used to, and on getting a variety of foods. There's no such thing as "junk" food. It's food. Food is healthy. You body needs it. There's no such thing as "empty calories". Like... if all you ate was nothing but twinkies, you'd get sick. The human body needs a range of things to be healthy. That doesn't actually make twinkies unhealthy. If you only ate apples, you would also get sick. If you only ate rabbit, you would get sick. If you only ate kale, you would get sick. There are no "unhealthy" foods other than poison. The problem of the health epidemic is one of misinformation on how the basis of dietary health works; that dietary misinformation creates industries and products to cell new solutions to non-problems. It's not new. The problem is that people's understanding of the foundation of it is wrong; not sugar. But the public generally believes that correlation implies causation, without looking at the full breadth of the picture. :/

That water bottle is not a good product; sorry.
snippet.textOriginal:

The water bottle, however, is proprietary, and the circles are made to only fit the plastic bottle that they make. And if the product doesn't sell well, it will have been another source of even more plastic waste. Also, there's a really unfortunate misconception about soda causing obesity, and the statistical correlation between the two being conflated. Soda itself is actually fine. It's sugar water, and sugar is, contrary to the current dietary fad of misinformation, not unhealthy, and is actually difficult to biologically have too much of. Weight gain itself is a multifactor thing, and it involves genetics and lifestyle (such as exercise). In fact, diet is one of the least contributing factors, and genetics is extremely more significant. Sugar itself is actually the chemical that human biology evolved to use as the necessary chemical for basic function and energy transfer. Protein and vitamins are what your body is built out of; not what makes it go. The ATP cycle uses sugar, specifically. Without it, you'd go into ketosis, which can be lethal. Soda is factually, biologically, fine. It's not "causing" obesity. It is nowhere close to that simple. And dietary health is based mostly on what your body is used to, and on getting a _variety_ of foods. There's no such thing as "junk" food. It's food. Food is healthy. You body needs it. There's no such thing as "empty calories". Like... if all you ate was nothing but twinkies, you'd get sick. The human body needs a range of things to be healthy. That doesn't actually make twinkies unhealthy. If you only ate apples, you would also get sick. If you only ate rabbit, you would get sick. If you only ate kale, you would get sick. There are no "unhealthy" foods other than poison. The _problem_ of the health epidemic is one of misinformation on how the basis of dietary health works; that dietary misinformation creates industries and products to cell new solutions to non-problems. It's not new. The problem is that people's understanding of the foundation of it is wrong; not sugar. But the public generally believes that correlation implies causation, without looking at the full breadth of the picture. :/

That water bottle is not a good product; sorry.
